titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John A. Nietz Papers UA.90.F95
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Marianne Kasica.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-14T13:59-0400

did.abstract: John A. Nietz was a professor in the School of Education at the University of Pittsburgh from 1926 to his retirement in 1958 and was renowned for his collection of old school textbooks.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Marianne Kasica from September 2013-May 2014. Prior organization was done while the collection was housed in the Special Collections Department.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of John A. Nietz in 1958.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: John A. Nietz was a professor in the School of Education at the University of Pittsburgh from 1926 to his retirement in 1958 and was renowned for his research on the history of education and his collection of old school textbooks.

Nietz was born near Toledo, Ohio, in 1888. He earned an A.B. degree at Ohio Northern University in 1914, a M.A. at Ohio State University in 1919, and a Ph.D. in Education at the University of Chicago in 1933. During his stay at the University of Chicago, Nietz studied under the famous philosopher and educational theorist, John Dewey.

Nietz was married to Ruby K. Nietz, who died in 1953, and was the father of Martha Nietz (Stoops). He later married Florence Metcalf Nietz. Nietz held several positions prior to his appointment at Pitt including a teacher at Wood County, Ohio, public schools, Superintendent at Maumee, Ohio, and Perrysburg, Ohio, public schools and Dean of the Murphy Collegiate Institute in Sevierville, Tennessee.

His research interests were many and included the history of public education, school administration, international education and old school textbooks. When he retired in 1958, he founded the Nietz Old Textbook Collection by donating his 9,000 volume library of early primary and secondary school texts to the library of the University of Pittsburgh. He had acquired the texts to demonstrate the history of teaching in the early years of the United States. During his career, Dr. Nietz directed or advised over 30 dissertations and master's theses based upon the collection. Dr. Nietz died in 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of John A. Nietz, a professor in the School of Education at the University of Pittsburgh. Much of the collection deals with Nietz' correspondence with students and educators and with the acquisition of the Nietz Old Textbook Collection. In addition there are research files both for his teaching career as well as his scholarly publications. Included is also correspondence about the following organizations, Pennsylvania Association for Adult Education; Pennsylvania State Education Association; Pittsburgh Council on Intercultural Education and Phi Delta Kappa.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The Nietz Papers were housed in the Special Collections department until their transfer to the University Archives in 2013.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Master's Thesis: Development of Public Secondary Education in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania by Edith R. Wilkinson was transferred to University of Pittsburgh Student Manuscripts Collection UA 90.9.22-T
Manuscript: University Extension by C. Stanton Belfour was transferred to the University Archives Personal Files under Belfour, C. Stanton.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of selected textbooks from the 19th Century Schoolbooks Collection are available electronically at http://digital.library.pitt.edu/nietz/.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into nine series:
Series IV. Manuscripts, Drafts, Articles, Chapters and Notes

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John A. Nietz Papers, 1800-1970, UA.90.F95, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series features the professional correspondence of John Nietz. Most of these letters deal with teaching at the University, oversight of dissertations, teacher training and evaluations, and job placement for graduates of Pittsburgh as well as other universities. The letters during the war years, 1940-1949, reflect correspondence about studies interrupted by military service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence that is of a more personal nature to family members and close friends. It is possible that there is some correspondence with people who were personal friends as well as colleagues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence on the acquisition of the Old Textbook collection. While Nietz had a substantial collection of early text books from 1922-1929, the acquisition activity increases in the 1930's and 1940's and then tapers off in the 1950's.

did.unittitle: Manuscripts, Drafts, Articles, Chapters and Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series has manuscripts and drafts of various writings that Nietz wrote or shared authorship of. Often files are partial chapters and some remain unidentified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Includes two essays: "Early Pitt Head an Pioneer in Professional Education" (about Gilbert Morgan), "Origin and Development of the University of Pittsburgh" and a report for the School of Education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes

did.unittitle: American School Board Journal issues with Nietz Articles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Nietz' research interests were varied but include public school administration, history of education in the U.S. and abroad, non traditional education such as correspondence schools or prison education and testing methods. Nietz travelled in Europe and met with ministers of education to collect information about educational systems there. It was difficult to determine Research Files versus Teaching Files in some cases so there will be some overlap between this and the next series, Teaching Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials that might have been used for teaching of his classes as well as examples and research from other people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains some files on various organizations that Nietz belonged to or had some interest in. In addition there are some of his speaking engagements, some materials on his daughter Martha and his composition books from the University of Chicago.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Minutes, reports and other documents of the organization during Nietz' time as a member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The photographs are primarily of Nietz' professional and research interests. There is one file of family photos. The file called Assorted Photographs may possibly have family members as well as others.

did.unittitle: Pittsburgh School District, Schools Past and Present Exhibit

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: McGuffy Memorial; Synn Family; Chart of Early Land Titles; Iatoollah a Hooshmail; Unidentifiled Girl; Higher Education in Poland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Over the course of his professional and personal life Nietz collected various artifacts dealing with education. Some items in this series, while interesting, seem unrelated to his interests.
